name: integrate_linear_rectifiable
description: Prove linearity of integration for rectifiable sets: ∫_Z (c·ω₁ + ω₂) = c·∫_Z ω₁ + ∫_Z ω₂
context: This is linearity of integration. hausdorffIntegrate is defined as (∫ x in carrier, formVectorPairing ω orientation x ∂measure).re. Use linearity of the Bochner integral from Mathlib (MeasureTheory.integral_add, integral_smul) and linearity of formVectorPairing and Complex.re.

name: stokes_bound_rectifiable
description: Prove Stokes' theorem bound for rectifiable sets
context: Stokes' theorem: ∫_Z dω = ∫_∂Z ω. For rectifiable sets, this relates the integral of the exterior derivative to the boundary integral. This is a deep GMT theorem - Federer's formulation of Stokes for rectifiable currents.

name: integrate_linear_closed
description: Prove linearity of integration for closed submanifolds
context: Same as integrate_linear_rectifiable but for ClosedSubmanifoldData. Should follow from linearity of hausdorffIntegrate.

name: stokes_bound_closed
description: Prove Stokes' theorem for closed submanifolds: ∫_Z dω = 0
context: For CLOSED submanifolds (no boundary), Stokes' theorem says ∫_Z dω = ∫_∂Z ω = 0 since ∂Z = ∅. This should be simpler than the general case.

name: rawsheetsum_stokes_bound
description: Prove Stokes' bound for RawSheetSum integration data
context: The stokes_bound field requires showing |∫_Z dω| ≤ boundary_mass * comass(ω). For the zero stub, this should be trivial since |0| ≤ 0.

name: rawsheetsum_is_integral
context: Show that the current constructed from RawSheetSum is integral. For the zero stub, zero_int is already integral by isIntegral_zero_current.

name: rawsheetsum_mass_bound
context: Show |setIntegral T Z ω| ≤ 0 for the zero integral current. This should follow from the fact that the integral is 0.

name: harveylawson_represents_input
description: Prove Harvey-Lawson witness represents the input class
context: This is the core of Harvey-Lawson: given a Hodge class γ, construct an integral current T representing it. The witness theorem says such T exists for positive closed currents. This is a deep theorem in complex geometry.
